abstract.text: A node that’s defined in an archived
file.

inlineContent.text: file to refer to node defined in another
file without duplicating its definition. This way, a change to the referenced node propagates to all the references in other files.
is mostly used in conjunction with Xcode’s SpriteKit Scene editor, but it’s possible to instantiate it yourself and use the
function as a handy way to restore a node’s appearance.

As an example, you might want to share an enemy ship across two different levels, Scene1.sks and Scene2.sks, in a level-based game. Reference nodes allow you to do that without creating copies of the shared node and its properties.
Create the shared content in a separate archive
Add references to the shared archive within your scene archives
When each scene is loaded, the reference nodes are resolved dynamically, and therefore you only need to configure a shared object in one place.

abstract.text: Add high-performance 2D content with smooth animations to your app, or create a game with a high-level set of 2D game-based tools.
A node that determines which parts of the scene are visible within a view.
The base class of all SpriteKit nodes.

file.
A method called by SpriteKit after the reference node’s contents are loaded.
A method that initializes a reference node from an archive.

Creates a reference node from a file in the app’s main bundle.

Loads the reference node’s content and adds it as a new child node.

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
